awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Berkeley Research Experiences for Teachers plus Data Science (BERET+D)
awd_abstract_narration:
This RET site at the University of California Berkeley entitled, "RET Site: Berkeley Research Experiences for Teachers plus Data Science (BERET+D)", will focus on research aimed at introducing pre-service and in-service math and science teachers to the use of data science in understanding, analyzing and visualizing engineering and science data, including distributed data sets from science centers across campus. A key element of the BERET+D program is support for teachers to acquire the necessary pedagogical content knowledge to engage their own K-12 students in data science. In-service and pre-service teacher teams will conduct research in a variety of engineering labs and science centers at UC Berkeley. Teacher teams will also participate in a sequence of summer and academic-year professional development activities that support them in translating their research into curriculum. BERET+D will pair pre-service teachers enrolled in the UC Berkeley CalTeach program with experienced in-service teachers serving predominantly underrepresented students in partnering public school districts. These teacher teams will develop essential research, analysis and visualization skills by engaging in data science research. Based on their common research experience, the teacher teams will develop curricula that connect current research to K-12 science and mathematics education and inspire students to see STEM as an exciting career with real-life applications. The teachers are guided in their research efforts by lab-based mentors who will gain instructional experience by serving as research advisers during the summer and as teaching partners in the K-12 classroom during the academic year. In addition, leadership opportunities will be provided to participating teachers by supporting them to co-facilitate academic year professional development workshops.

BERET+D will contribute to engineering and scientific research, and K-12 education by supporting teachers to conduct research in the field, learn effective strategies for integrating data science into their classroom instruction, and develop, use and disseminate standards-based curricula. BERET+D will guide teachers to gain an understanding of the processes of conducting research, especially involving large data sets, by engaging in in-depth, authentic research and scaffolded reflections on these experiences in professional development activities. BERET+D will prepare participants to incorporate their research experiences into their classrooms and engage their K-12 students in both understanding and dealing with significant data sets. CalTeach will use RET program data as part of its ongoing efforts in research on teacher education and professional development, evaluating how the unique partnership (between pre-service teachers, in-service teachers, and graduate students) functions in doing authentic engineering research and co-implementing related curriculum in the classroom.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Berkeley Engineering Research Experiences for Teachers plus Computing (BERET+D) program engaged current and future K-12 science and math teachers in engineering and data science research projects to further develop teachers’ understanding of the process of scientific research, related pedagogy and curriculum development for guiding their students to practice engineering and data science research skills, and awareness of engineering and data science career pathways. Teacher pairs made up of experienced math and science teachers and undergraduate science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) majors committed to becoming a teacher were placed in multi-disciplinary research laboratories within STEM departments at UC Berkeley. These included Departments of Nuclear Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Chemistry, Genetics and Plant Biology, Astronomy, as well as the Lawrence Berkeley Labs, Berkeley’s Division of Computing, Data Science & Society, and the Berkeley School of Education.

Careful recruitment resulted in a diverse population of participants with the intention of supporting secondary math and science teachers from schools with students underrepresented in STEM. For example, 16% of ISTs identified as Black and 20% as Latinx compared 10% and 13% of teachers in the nation, respectively. Additionally, 75% of PSTs identified as teachers of color, but only 23% nationally. Finally, regarding gender, nearly 5% of our PSTs identified as nonbinary, as compared to nearly 0% nationally. Across all participants, and over four years, our recruiting resulted in higher percentages of minority involvement as compared to national averages across nearly every demographic category. 

Over the four-year period of the award, a total of 84 summer research placements were made in which teachers conducted independent research projects in research groups in which faculty mentors, postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students were active, available, and involved. Teacher pairs used their summer research experiences as the basis for developing new lessons and curricular materials for K-12 classrooms that specifically highlight aspects of engineering and data science. During and after the summer research experience, teachers collaborated to develop several innovative hands-on engineering- and data science-based curricular units of several days to several weeks that they jointly taught in the K-12 classrooms during the academic year following the BERET+D summer. Additionally, STEM undergraduates developed over 63 lesson plans based on their research, which they intend to implement in their future classrooms.

Other program activities included: (1) collaborative opportunities for research faculty and graduate student mentors while implementing BERET+D curriculum in K-12 classrooms, (2) annual program-wide events that brought together participants, research mentors, university faculty, and high school students, to collaborate and exchange ideas around problems of practice in wide ranging data science contexts, and (3), extensive program evaluation and research providing insight into the impact of undergraduate and teacher research experiences. Studying impacts of the BERET+D program has led to specific research-based recommendations for designers of Research Experiences for Teachers programs at other organizations and universities. They have also provided critical insight into what undergraduates and current teachers learn from research experiences, helped uncover the gaps in participants’ understanding of their research projects, and showed us the ways in which undergraduates take what they learn into their classrooms later when they become teachers. Such research findings have helped faculty research mentors, as well as undergraduate and teacher research programs, improve what these experiences offer to future participants. 

A number of conference presentations to STEM teacher educators at national conferences, as well as one publication, have resulted from BERET+D program activities. These include a webinar on engaging pre-service teachers in STEM research, a presentation discussing the successes and challenges in recruiting and engaging in-service teachers in summer research opportunities, and a series of posters describing how data science is used to study metabolic pathways and how this can be taught to high school biology students. Additional manuscripts related to this project are currently being prepared for peer-reviewed science education journals.
